byline.contributor: Alan Blinder reported from North Charleston and Manny Fernandez from Houston. Frances Robles and Ben Rothenberg contributed reporting from North Charleston. Andrew W. Lehren contributed research from Washington, and Sarah Cohen from New York.
byline.original: By ALAN BLINDER and MANNY FERNANDEZ

abstract: Forceful tactics used by mostly white police force in North Charleston, SC, have decreased violent crime rates but cost of strategy is high; black residents say they have been harassed and racially profiled ever since new aggressive police campaign was initiated to combat city's label of 'dangerous' in 2007; strategy came to forefront in latest police shooting of unarmed black man Walter L Scott.
lead_paragraph: To many in North Charleston, aggressive policing lends a disturbing context to the shooting last weekend that has caused outrage across the country.

headline.main: South Carolina Police Shooting Seen as Crime Strategy Gone Awry
headline.print_headline: Residents Trace Police Shooting to a Crime Strategy Gone Awry

snippet: To many in North Charleston, aggressive policing lends a disturbing context to the shooting last weekend that has caused outrage across the country.
